tossups.question: In one work from this country, Holocaust victims try to use a zombie skier and a zombie philosophy student to come back to life. In another work from this country of The Children of the Dead, a man endlessly tries to perfect his sister’s cone-shaped house. One author from this country created “The poet and the actress,” “the actress and the count,” and “the count and the whore” as part of the title ring of unfaithful couples, and he wrote about a man who resents his wife’s fantasies and sneaks into a masked orgy. "La Ronde" and "Dream Story," the basis for Eyes Wide Shut, were from this country. This country is home to Elfriede (*) Jelinek, Arthur Schnitzler, and Thomas Bernard, whose work Correction was inspired by this country's philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein. For 10 points, name this country where Freud wrote The Interpretation of Dreams.
tossups.answer: Austria [accept Austria-Hungary]

tossups.question: Ibn Kathir defended his teacher Ibn Taymiyyah’s criticism of this practice as shirk, citing a hadith about shadd al-rihal in which Muhammad went back on his position concerning it by saying it will “weaken your attachment to the world.” The Jamiah kabirah prayer is often recited by Twelver Shias while performing a form of this practice at Imamzadeh; that form of this practice is called ziyarat. The practices of Sai and (*) Tawwaf are central to one form of this practice whose “lesser” form is called Umrah. A year after the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah, Muhammad and the companions performed what is commonly referred to as the first instance of this practice. People must be in a state of ihram to perform this practice, which involves drinking from the Zamzam well and circling the Kaa’ba seven times. Eid al-Adha marks the end of a form of, for 10 points, what practice including visiting grave sites and going to Mecca for the Hajj?
tossups.answer: pilgrimage [accept ziyarat before mentioned; accept more specific pilgrimages like Hajj before mentioned; include specific descriptions of similar practices like visiting the graves of saints; do not accept or prompt on “intercession” after “shadd al-rihal”; before “shadd al-rihal,” accept intercession of saints or Muhammad since Ibn Taymiyyah criticized those practices in addition to the practice of visiting graves]

tossups.question: A jurist from this region named Manuel Crescencio Rejón developed a form of judicial review protecting individual rights known as the writ of amparo in its constitution. In 1905, hundreds of Korean immigrants left Incheon to work on the henequen plantations in this region. White stars on a green field adjacent to red and white stripes adorn the flag of this region that was adopted by seceding federalists under Miguel Barbachano and Santiago Mendez. The Cult of the Talking Cross infused native religion into a rebellion in this region led by Jacinto Pat and Cecilio Chi and centered at (*) Chan Santa Cruz. Competing governments in this region’s cities of Mérida and Campeche reunified with the central government after the fall of Santa Anna in exchange for help in their Caste War. For 10 points, name this heavily Mayan-populated Mexican peninsula.
tossups.answer: Yucatán Peninsula [prompt on Mexico; prompt on southern Mexico]

tossups.question: The apparatus for this technique contains a suppressor to decrease background electrical signals. It’s not adsorption, but the apparatus used in this technique is usually tested by plotting a breakthrough curve. Increasing salt concentration or citrate concentration is one method of elution in this technique. A conductometric detector is commonly used alongside this technique. Either the Clark process or this process is used to (*) soften water. This technique often uses Amberjet, Dowex or DEAE resins. When this technique is used on proteins, the pH of the medium is set either above or below the isoelectric point to maximize binding based on charge interactions. For 10 points, name this form of chromatography in which molecules are separated by charges.
tossups.answer: ion exchange [or ion exchange chromatography; or IEC; or anion-exchange chromatography or cation-exchange chromatography; prompt on column chromatography; prompt on water treatment or water softening before “water” is mentioned]

tossups.question: Richard Strauss adapted a menuet by this composer in a suite which was originally intended to be part of the same production as the opera Ariadne auf Naxos. Early in his career, this composer wrote ballet music for Francesco Cavalli’s Ercole amante. He’s not Gluck or Handel, but one of his operatic heroines is too smitten with the knight Renaud (“re-NOH”) to kill him. That opera was based on Jerusalem Delivered by Torquato Tasso, with libretto by Jean-Philippe (*) Quinault (“kee-NOH”). Richard Strauss’s suite Le Bourgeois gentilhomme was inspired by this composer’s music for Molière’s play of the same name. He introduced the tragédie en musique, or tragédie lyrique, in such operas as Armide and Alceste, which he wrote while Superintendent of Music under Louis XIV. For 10 points, name this Italian-born French Baroque composer who died after hitting his foot with his conducting staff.
tossups.answer: Jean-Baptiste Lully [or Giovanni Battista Lulli]

tossups.question: One character created by this author is "thankful to God" that "no one has danced in our district for eight years"; that story ends with the image of a "flaunting quean" "dressed in all her finery" who calls men "Pigs! Pigs!" A barmaid created by this author sleeps with multiple men because "we shall all be dead in a hundred years." This author wrote about the missionary Davidson's persecution of the prostitute Sadie Thompson in (*) "Rain." This author created the social-climbing Elliot Templeton and described the pilot Larry Darrell's decision to shun society life and become an Eastern mystic in another novel. Another novel by this author describes Ashenden's reminiscences about the writer's muse Rosie Driffield. For 10 points, name this author of The Razor's Edge and Cakes and Ale, who wrote about the clubfooted Philip Carey in Of Human Bondage.
tossups.answer: W. Somerset Maugham [pronounced “maum,” but an attempt at a phonetic pronunciation is also fine]

tossups.question: It’s not development, growth, or molting, but Michael Adams studies pupal ecdysis as an example of one of these phenomena triggered by ETH. Eibl-Eisenfeldt suggested that the “eyebrow flash” in humans is one example of these phenomena. These phenomena are hijacked by code-breakers, who often use supernormal stimuli to trigger them. Key features of these phenomena include independence from experience and species-specificity, as suggested by Konrad (*) Lorenz. Key examples of these behaviors include digger wasps kicking intruders out of their nest, egg rolling in greylag geese, and stickleback fish attacking anything with a red belly. For 10 points, name these behaviors that, when triggered by a sign stimulus, must be completed.
tossups.answer: Fixed Action Patterns [or FAP; accept modal action pattern or MAP; prompt on “instincts”, “instinctual behaviors”]

tossups.question: According to the Miao people, A Zie wished to marry his sister following one of these events brought about by Lei Gong being released from his cage. Gong Gong inadvertently caused one of these events after he caused the sky to crumble by banging his head into a mountain. Yi was eventually made the Minister of Animal Husbandry for his support of the emperor during one of these events. One of these events prompted the Count of Chong to steal xirang from (*) Shangdi, for which he was executed on Feather Mountain. Gun rose to power after the Four Mountains advised Emperor Yao to seek his help during one of these events. Hou Ji collaborated with a future emperor to devise a system to address one of these events which self-expanding soil wasn’t effective in solving. Yu the Great founded the Xia dynasty after building an irrigation system to help solve the problem of, for 10 points, the “Great” variety of what type of disastrous events in China commonly stemming from the Yellow River?
tossups.answer: floods

tossups.question: The ad agency Tandem designed a set of posters to promote this policy featuring all-caps “gaspipe lettering” and muted color palettes. In a short film about this policy, Molly Crabapple draws time-lapse watercolor sketches of a train to Washington, DC. An emoji illustrates and partially titles the cover of a book that makes “the case for” this policy; that 2019 book is by Naomi Klein. This policy’s name was popularized by the Sunrise Movement, which drew attention to it by holding a (*) sit-in inside the offices of Nancy Pelosi. A resolution on this program failed 57-0 after 43 senators voted “present” in protest. This program calls for a “10-year national mobilization” that would upgrade American infrastructure, and critics have alleged that it would ban hamburgers and planes. For 10 points, name this ambitious climate proposal whose name references a program created under FDR.
tossups.answer: the Green New Deal [or GND; accept H.Res.109 or S.Res.59; do not accept or prompt on “New Deal” alone] (The book is “On 🔥: The Burning Case for a Green New Deal.”)

tossups.question: The trial of John Bodkin Adams may have been tampered with because of the fear that a guilty verdict would lead to this program’s collapse. A.J. Cronin’s popular novel The Citadel conceptualized this system based on his experience in Tredegar. The 1957 Guillebaud Report assuaged concerns about this program’s longevity, though the recent Nicholson Challenge targeted twenty billion (*) pounds in efficiency savings by 2015. Ken Clarke oversaw the introduction of the internal market and GP fundholding to this system in 1990, though they were replaced with PCTs by Tony Blair. Aneurin (“uh-NYE-rin”) Bevan was the architect of this program based on the Beveridge Report’s welfare state recommendations. For 10 points, name this state healthcare system of the United Kingdom.
tossups.answer: National Health Service [or NHS; prompt on descriptions of Britain’s healthcare system]

tossups.question: A 2008 study by Fu and Kane showed that Majorana bound states can appear at the interface between these materials and superconductors, building on previous work by Kane and Mele that predicted the quantum spin Hall effect in them. A simple model Hamiltonian for these materials has a large on-site repulsion term compared to the inter-site hopping term in the Hubbard model. Bismuth selenide is the prototypical example of a subtype of these materials with a single Dirac cone. They are not antiferromagnets, but electron-electron interactions are responsible for the (*) Mott type of these materials. Most of these materials have a very large band gap between the valence and conduction bands. For 10 points, name these materials which do not allow current to pass, contrasted with conductors.
tossups.answer: insulators [or topological insulators or Mott insulators]

tossups.question: Writing in Realism With a Human Face, Hilary Putnam accused this philosopher of settling for “half-truths,” or what this thinker called “warranted assertability.” Richard Posner wrote a 2003 book partially concerned with this thinker’s legal philosophy, which Posner summarized by studying this philosopher’s paper “Logical Method and Law.” This thinker argued that artistic objects should not be “separated from both conditions of origin and operation in (*) experience” in his major work on aesthetics, Art as Experience. Reacting against Walter Lippman, this philosopher argued for a political order that allowed for “fulfillment of personal potentialities… in rich and manifold associations with others,” in The Public and Its Problems. For 10 points, identify this philosopher who coined the concept of the “reflex arc” and described the interaction between learning and political life in Democracy and Education.
tossups.answer: John Dewey

tossups.question: This novel's protagonist says that her great-grandfather threw a sack over her great-grandmother's head and carried her off "as if she were a fancy chandelier." Characters in this novel include "Cathy, Queen of Cats"; Darius, who claims that "that fat [cloud] there" is God; and the university student Alicia, who fears imaginary mice. Characters sing "Yes, no, maybe so" as they jump rope in this novel; those characters, Rachel and Lucy, practice walking in (*) heels. This novel describes a place which came after Loomis and Keeler and is supposed to be temporary and ends with the narrator's parting declaration to come back “For the ones I left behind." This novel’s protagonist is sexually assaulted at a carnival and wants to call herself Zeze the X. For 10 points, name this Sandra Cisneros novel about the teenage Esperanza Cordero, who lives in the title abode.
tossups.answer: The House on Mango Street

tossups.question: A group led by this artist took the pseudonym “Jones-Smith Incorporated” because this artist already had a contract with Decca. A live broadcast of this artist’s group playing at the Reno Club caught the attention of record producer John Hammond, who helped bring this musician to national prominence. The song “Li’l Darlin” was arranged by Neal Hefti for the album The Atomic Mr. [this man]. His rhythm section included guitarist (*) Freddie Green for decades, and Jo Jones on drums during the ‘30s and ‘40s. This man’s band originally formed from alumni of Benny Moten’s band after Moten’s early death. He is credited with popularizing Kansas City Jazz and its spare piano style, and the signature tunes of his band included “Jumpin’ at the Woodside” and “One O’Clock Jump.” For 10 points, name this jazz pianist and bandleader, nicknamed “Count.”
tossups.answer: Count Basie [or William James Basie]

tossups.question: Bus snooping is used to maintain coherency between many of these things. An idealized model of these things assumes they have maximum size big omega of objects squared; that assumption refers to them as “tall” and is used to model algorithms that are “oblivious” to these things. The ideal algorithm for controlling these things is the “optimal replacement policy” or Belady’s algorithm, but in practice adaptive replacement, MRU, and (*) LRU are used instead. The hit ratio quantifies the efficiency of this component. This component uses temporal and spatial locality, and usually occurs in 3 levels, with the first divided split into “data” and “instruction” components. For 10 points, name this component of the CPU that stores recently-accessed data.
tossups.answer: cache [prompt on memory, do not accept “RAM” or “random access memory”]

tossups.question: In this election, Robert McCormick’s opposition to Illinois governor Dwight Green prevented him from becoming the Republican vice presidential candidate. Columnist Westbrook Pegler created controversy in this election by publishing the letters between one third-party candidate and his (*) Russian spiritual guru. The eventual nominee declared “you can’t shoot an idea with a gun” to primary candidate Harold Stassen in the first-ever presidential radio debate, which was held during this election. During this election, the incumbent president called a special session of Congress on “Turnip Day” and dared the “Do-Nothing Congress” to pass its platform. The inclusion of a strong civil rights plank in this election led to a Southern walkout at the Democratic convention and Strom Thurmond’s Dixiecrat ticket. For 10 points, name this election that spawned a Chicago Tribune headline proclaiming “Dewey Defeats Truman.”
tossups.answer: U.S. presidential election of 1948 [prompt on ‘48] (The third-party candidate in the second line is Henry Wallace)

tossups.question: Direct objects in this language can inherit the subject’s plural marker when the subject is plural and the direct object is uncountable. The expression “eykey” (“EH-geh”) in this language can mark either the agent or the location-goal in a sentence, but not both. Unlike the standard form of this language, one of its dialects uses tones and preserves [s] and [b] from this language’s middle form. All eight of this language’s vowels once had length distinctions, but those have now been almost entirely neutralized. This language has (*) seven speech levels, and the ways consonants in this language are written is based on the shape the mouth makes when articulating them. That writing system was developed by Sejong the Great and is called Hangul. For 10 points, name this most widely spoken language isolate, spoken primarily in two countries with capitals at Pyongyang and Seoul.
tossups.answer: Korean [or Hanguk-eo; or Hanguk-mal; prompt on "Hangul" before mention]

tossups.question: For one series, this artist prevented color variation in his homemade casein (“KAY-seen”) tempera by painting all the panels in parallel one color at a time. Because of this artist’s renown, he and his wife Gwendolyn Knight were not included in the Spiral Group. Mexican muralism influenced the “dynamic cubism” of a series by this artist with even and odd number panels split by the MoMA and the Phillips Collection. A zigzagging golden rope divides the two sections of a flat, beige canvas depicting a (*) restaurant in a painting by this artist. A series by this artist depicts three girls writing the numbers “2, 3, 4” on an otherwise empty chalkboard. He used long captions for a series that depicts a crowd of silhouettes filing through doors labeled “Chicago,” “New York,” and “St. Louis.” For 10 points, name this African-American painter of the Migration Series.
tossups.answer: Jacob Lawrence

tossups.question: In this book, the image of a woman walking down the beach singing “Yesterday” is conflated with the image of a boy riding a horse through smoke. The work’s narrator meets the ghost of his father Warwick, who is late to a barber’s appointment. One segment of this work features the narrator traveling from New England to London to Ireland and reading the letters of Catherine Weldon, who witnessed the Ghost Dance. Two men argue over a tin cup in this novel, one of whom owns a (*) canoe called In God We Troust. Maud claims that a yellow dress was stolen in this work, where Major Plunkett and the blind man Seven Seas frequents Ma Kilman’s No Pain Cafe. The pregnant Helen is fought over by the fishermen Achille and Hector in this work. For 10 points, name this epic poem by Derek Walcott, a Saint Lucian postmodernist retelling of the Iliad named after Homer.
tossups.answer: Omeros

tossups.question: A soldier legendarily told an SS officer “You see [this] city? That's Walter!” when asked to find its rebel leader. Citizens raised a green flag at Gazi Husrev-beg mosque to oppose the occupation of this city, and the People’s Government led this city’s resistance to the plans laid out in the Andrássy Note. International coverage of five-year-old Irma’s mortar injuries led John Major to begin airlift evacuations from this city, where the (*) Markale (“MAHR-kel-eh”) massacres precipitated Operation Deliberate Force. It’s not Benghazi, but Hillary Clinton stirred controversy by falsely claiming that as First Lady she braved gunfire in this city, where signs reading “Watch Out!--Sniper” became commonplace. The nationalist Gavrilo Princip took advantage of a royal visit to this city to assassinate Franz Ferdinand. For 10 points, name this capital subject to a four-year-siege during the Bosnian War.
tossups.answer: Sarajevo

bonuses.leadin: This character destroyed a letter intended for his father after realizing that he would have to arrest his father for supporting Napoleon based on the information it contained. For 10 points each:
answers: Gérard De Villefort [accept either underlined part]
Mercedes Mondego [or Mercedes Herrera; prompt on Mondego or Herrera]
parts: Name this character, the chief prosecutor in Marseilles who sends the titular protagonist of the novel he appears in to prison in the Chateau d’If.
Villefort appears in this novel by Alexandre Dumas about Edmond Dantès’ wrongful imprisonment and subsequent quest for revenge.

In The Count of Monte Cristo, this woman is Dantes’ fiancee, who ends up marrying Fernand Mondego and having a son Albert. Upset at this, Edmond very sassily refuses to eat some Muscatel grapes this woman offers him.

bonuses.leadin: This work is framed as a conversation between an unnamed Athenian visitor, the Spartan Megillus, and the Cretan Kleinias, who are attempting to devise a constitution for the colony of Magnesia. For 10 points each:
answers: atheism [accept equivalents like the nonexistence of god or gods]
parts: Identify this Platonic dialogue which describes the political system that would be established by the title institutions. This is the longest Platonic dialogue.
Book X of The Laws contains an extended argument by the Athenian that uses the soul as the engine of the motion of celestial bodies as evidence against this philosophical position.
The presence of “preludes,” or philosophical justifications, in The Laws differentiates that work from this more famous work by Plato, which contains a notable allegory about a cave.

bonuses.leadin: Along with cholesterol and triglycerides, this compound is commonly found in hepatic bile and serves as an emulsifier. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these lipids which are the major component of cell membranes; they traditionally consist of glycerol bound to two fatty acids and a namesake polar head group named for the group 15 element it contains.
Most neutral phospholipids have either ethanolamine or this head group that contains a quaternary amine.
This sugar, commonly found in brain tissue, is the head group of phospholipids like PIP (“pip”). In that lipid this sugar’s phosphorylation state acts as an intracellular signal.

bonuses.leadin: Though most are now Christian or Muslim, members of this ethnic group once practiced the monotheistic Waaqeffanna religion. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ethnic group that practices the traditional Gadaa (“gad-AH”) system of social stratification, cycling males upward in status every eight years. These people were pejoratively called the “Galla” by rival Amharas and Tigrayans.

Oromos constitute the plurality ethnic group in this African country, which was ruled by a line of emperors from the Solomonic Dynasty until the assassination of Haile Selassie (“HI-lee seh-LASS-ee”).

This current prime minister of Ethiopia joined the Oromo Democratic Party to fight the Derg in the ‘90s. This politician won the 2019 Nobel Peace Prize for resolving Ethiopia’s twenty-year conflict with Eritrea.

bonuses.leadin: Beginning in the Song dynasty, this material was pigmented with cinnabar and often carved with a pattern of repeating oblong trefoils to expose multiple layers in the guri technique. For 10 points each:
answers: lacquer [or lacquerware; prompt on resin; do not accept or prompt on “varnish”]
cobalt [or cobalt-blue; or hui hui qing]
parts: Name this red material made from dried sap that was used to coat cups and bowls during the Ming and Qing dynasties. This material was carved in a technique known as diaoqi.
During the Zhou dynasty, temples were often decorated with bi disks, which were made of this precious green stone and intended to represent the circle of Heaven.

Imported Persian pigments based on this metal led to Jingdezhen (“jing-di-jin”) being the center of porcelain production during the Ming dynasty. Its oxide was used for the underglaze patterning that was then covered with a clear glaze.

bonuses.leadin: A transition between two of these states is categorized as first-order if one of the first derivatives of the free energy is discontinuous. For 10 points each:
answers: order parameter [prompt on m or psi or order]
parts: Name these states of matter which have uniform physical and chemical properties throughout their volume. They include gas, liquid, and plasma.
When a system is in equilibrium, all phases will have the same value for this quantity, symbolized mu. It represents the energy change due to adding another particle to the system.

At vapor-liquid equilibrium, this quantity is equal to the difference in density between the vapor and liquid. This general type of quantity describes which phase the system is in, and usually ranges from zero in one phase to nonzero in another.

bonuses.leadin: After this deity stole Enki’s mes while the latter was inebriated, he sent gallas to recover them. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this deity who went to Kur to visit Ereshkigal and is escorted out by gallas created from dirt from under Enki’s fingernails. This deity is often accompanied by Ninshubur.
Inanna was worshipped at the Eanna temple in the city of Uruk, once ruled by this hero who rejected her. This friend of Enkidu enlists him to help defeat Humbaba.
This creature resides with a serpent and Lilitu in a tree which Inanna wanted to chop down to make a throne. Ninurta killed this creature for stealing the Tablets of Destiny.

bonuses.leadin: In “The Epistemology of the Closet,” the quote "The escape would have been to love her; then, then he would have lived" has been used to theorize that this story's protagonist reflected its author's homosexuality. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this story, in which John Marcher believes that he is destined for a spectacular event lying in wait for him. He realizes he has thrown his life away by failing to realize that May Bartram was in love with him.

The author of "The Beast in the Jungle" also wrote a novella about this free-spirited title character, who is seen as flirtatious because she meets with Giovanelli in the Colosseum and dies from Roman fever.

Novels like Colm Toibin’s The Master have theorized that this author of "The Beast in the Jungle" and "Daisy Miller" was homosexual. He also wrote about the possible ghost of Peter Quint in “The Turn of the Screw.”

bonuses.leadin: Jan Matthys died sallying forth to defend this city with only twelve followers because he believed himself to be the second Gideon. For 10 points each:
answers: Anabaptists [do not accept or prompt on “Baptists”]
parts: Name this city besieged by the exiled bishop Franz von Waldeck. John of Leiden took power in this city after Matthys’ death and executed Elisabeth Wandscherer for opposing his institution of polygamy.

Matthys and John of Leiden belonged to this Christian movement which stated its principles in the Schleitheim Confession and convened a 1550 synod in Venice. The Amish and Mennonites developed as offshoots of this movement.
Matthys identified Münster with the “New [this city].” The Book of Ezekiel declares that this city will be the capital of the Messianic Kingdom where a new King of Israel will be anointed.

bonuses.leadin: The composer of this symphony substituted a setting of the Magnificat for the planned third movement, at the suggestion of Richard Wagner. For 10 points each:
answers: Dante Symphony [or A Symphony to Dante’s Divine Comedy; or Eine Symphonie zu Dantes Divina Commedia]
parts: Name this programmatic symphony for orchestra and women’s chorus. The composer had earlier written a “fantasia quasi sonata” inspired by the same source material.
The Dante Symphony was written by this composer and virtuoso pianist, who also composed 19 Hungarian Rhapsodies inspired by Gypsy music.

As a pianist, Liszt freely employed this technique, known by an Italiam name, in which the performer alters the rhythm for expressive purposes, often by slowing down part of a bar and speeding up the rest.

bonuses.leadin: This silvery-white metal is essential to the Lindlar catalyst. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this transition metal which is a catalyst for many coupling reactions. A common hydrogenation catalyst consists of this element on carbon, and like platinum it is commonly found in catalytic converters.
Palladium is used in the catalyst in this coupling reaction of an aryl boronic acid and an aryl halide. It is named after a Japanese chemist.
In the Suzuki coupling, halides can be replaced by triflates and other compounds containing these polyatomic ions that react like halides. These polyatomic ions include cyanide and azide.

bonuses.leadin: One of Shiva’s wives is the third form of Durga, named for a half moon shaped like one of these objects. For 10 points:
parts: Name these objects called ghantas (“GHUN-tas”) which hang outside Hindu temples, where people interact with them before entering.
Bells may be adorned with different creatures including an eagle representing Garuda, the mount of this preserver deity.
A bell may be paired with sounds of a conch shell during this part of a puja in which fire is presented to an image of a deity while the congregation sings.

bonuses.leadin: In one work, this man is helped by men nicknamed “Sky Rat,” “Earth Rat,” “Mountain Rat,” “River Rat,” and “Skee Rat” in his rise to office. For 10 points each:
answers: Judge Bao Zheng [accept Judge Bao Gong]
chalk circle [prompt on partial answer, accept Huī lán jì]
parts: Name this magistrate, who appears in many works of gong’an fiction including The Seven Heroes and Five Gallants, and in one work, solves a case where a man is killed by having nails driven into his brain.
In one Judge Bao play, the baby Shoulang is placed in one of these places, where the two potential mothers Hai-tang and Ah-Siu both try to pull him out.
That story inspired The Caucasian Chalk Circle by this fan of classical Chinese drama, the playwright of The Good Person of Szechwan and Mother Courage and Her Children.

bonuses.leadin: This ruler addressed criticism by publishing a satirical essay called Misopogon, or “Beard-Hater,” about himself. For 10 points each:
answers: Battle of Strasbourg [or Battle of Argentoratum]
parts: Name this Roman emperor of the Constantinian dynasty who published Against the Galileans, a polemical essay about Christianity, and ordered Alypius of Antioch to rebuild the Temple in Jerusalem.

As Caesar, or deputy emperor, Julian crushed an Alemanni army three times the size led by Chnodomar and drove them back across the Rhine at this 357 A.D. battle. Grandsons of Charlemagne took an 842 A.D. oath to oppose their brother Lothair in the city for which this battle is named.

Julian was proclaimed Augustus while stationed with his troops in Lutetia, the Roman name for this modern city. St. Denis, the first Bishop of this city, was executed on a hill here that later came to be known as Montmartre.

bonuses.leadin: The Palme d’Or is the highest award given at the Cannes Film Festival. For 10 points each,
parts: This 1976 Palme d’Or winner directed by Martin Scorcese stars Robert De Niro as a man planning to kill a presidential candidate.
This 2004 film directed by Michael Moore is one of only two documentaries that have won the Palme d’Or and focuses on the leadup to the Iraq War.
This New Zealand director is the only woman to have ever won the Palme d’Or, having won for her 1993 film The Piano.

bonuses.leadin: The University of Maryland economist Herman Daly heads a center to push this idea into the economic mainstream. For 10 points each:
answers: economic stagnation [accept secular stagnation; anti-prompt on stagflation]
parts: Name this condition in which an economy maintains a constant stock of goods and population, aiming for little consumption and almost no economic growth as classically defined.
Economics of the steady-state contrasts with an economics movement that predicts a future in which this condition will end, known as “post-[this condition].”
A steady-state economy is not the same as an economy undergoing this process, which was combined with “inflation” in a portmanteau characterizing late 1970’s economic conditions.

bonuses.leadin: The company behind this card warned users that its sleek coating may be discolored through contact with leather or denim, earning much online mockery. For 10 points each:
answers: Republic of Ireland [do not accept or prompt on “Northern Ireland”] (The second tax dodge mentioned is the “Double Irish.”)
parts: Name this credit card issued by Goldman Sachs in partnership with a namesake tech company. Its smooth titanium design matches those of its namesake’s popular computers and smartphones.

While integration between the Apple Card, Apple Pay, and the Apple Wallet is a selling point for consumers, it is being investigated as a potential antitrust violation by this Danish regulator, the European Commissioner for Competition.

Vestager also alleges Apple dodged $14 billion in taxes via this EU member country. US companies often use this non-Dutch country in tax schemes like tax inversions, a namesake “Double” BEPS tool, and a “Single Malt.”

bonuses.leadin: During his time as a schoolteacher, this man created the "Blue-Backed Speller" in order to update the American education system. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this lexicographer who published his now-namesake American Dictionary of the English Language in 1828.

Noah Webster lobbied strongly for an 1831 act revising this legal protection delegated to Congress in Article I, Section 8, Clause 8. A 1998 law concerning this legal protection was named for the late Sonny Bono.
Webster studied law under this Connecticut politician who chiefly authored the Judiciary Act. This third Chief Justice promoted ratification of the Constitution in Letters of a Landholder.

bonuses.leadin: Because this character “gathered all that springs to birth / From the many-venomed earth,” unnamed enemies “shook to see him drink it up” after “they poured strychnine in his cup.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this “king...in the East,” who “died old.” A story about this man is used to oppose the idea that “malt does more than Milton can / to justify God’s ways to man.”

The story of Mithridates is recounted in this poem, whose narrator mentions “the rate you drink your beer” to the title character before telling him “But oh, good Lord, the verse you make,/ It gives a chap the belly-ache.”
This author of “Terence, this is stupid stuff” also included the poem “When I was One-and-Twenty” in his collection A Shropshire Lad.

bonuses.leadin: Howie Choset adapted a flexible, high-degree-of-freedom snake robot to work as one of these systems. For 10 points each:
answers: robotic surgery systems [or minimally invasive surgery systems; or any combination of the two; prompt on Medrobotics]
parts: Name these devices, which include Intuitive’s Da Vinci machine and Stryker’s Mako. They typically allow results comparable to laparoscopy, but provide higher degrees of freedom with a master-slave system.
Robotic surgery systems are an example of this broad category of devices including catheters and pacemakers, which must be approved by the FDA.

Willem Einthoven invented this medical device, which he tested by sticking his feet into saline water. In this technique, a small box represents 0.04 seconds along its horizontal axis, while a large box represents 0.20 seconds.
